association between drug class and switching remained statistically similar when propensity score was included in the regression analysis. thiazide diuretics were significantly more likely to be switched compared to other major antihypertensive drug classes. patients first prescribed thiazide diuretics were significantly more likely to be switched, and a larger difference in switching was observed with time. higher levels of systolic blood pressure were associated with higher rates of switching. thiazide diuretics have been recommended as one of the first-line antihypertensive therapy for management of arterial hypertension. male patients, residents in more rural areas and those with at least one comorbid condition were more likely to be switchers. the influence of age on the tendency to switch medications has been discussed in a recent study. hypertensive agents among Chinese patients in real clinical practice may also play a role in antihypertensive drug switching. some might argue that the availability of new medications in the classes of medications in the study period, physician bias on selection of prescriptions, and inefficacy of the initial prescription might also explain medication switching behaviors. study provides clinicians and policy-makers with antihypertensive drug utilization profiles. low absolute rates of switching within 180 days after antihypertensive prescription should reassure physicians and their patients about the relatively low adverse reaction rates in the short-term. health service database of Lombardia, Italy, evaluated residents on antihypertensive treatment aged 40–80 years during 1999–2002. the six month switching rate was 15% [17]. similar database studies including pooled Italian, Swedish and Dutch cohorts reported a 9 month switching rate of 15.9% [30]. the influence of age on the tendency to switch medications has been discussed in a recent study where switching rates of beta-blockers increased markedly from 14% for those aged 40 years to 30% for patients aged >75 years [16]. however, conflicting data exist about whether male or female patients adhere better to antihypertensive treatments. medications in the classes of medications in the study period, physician bias on selection of prescriptions, implementation of local guidelines, and inefficacy of the initial prescription might also explain medication switching behaviors. a significant number of patients who visited the clinic only once, died within 180 days after the initial prescription, stayed in the cohort for less than 180 days. this might underestimate the real switching rate as they might be at higher risk of switching. the low absolute rates of switching within 180 days after antihypertensive prescription should reassure physicians and their patients about the relatively low adverse reaction rates in the short-term. the higher odds of switching among thiazide users, especially among the male subjects, warrant further evaluation.
